content: If you are facing north, is the North Star to your left or right?

As an AI language model, I don't have the ability to physically face directions or observe the sky. However, I can provide you with information based on general knowledge.

The North Star, also known as Polaris, is located almost directly above the North Pole. If you are facing north, the North Star should be approximately straight ahead in the sky, assuming you are in the Northern Hemisphere and have a clear view of the night sky.

To find the North Star, you can use the pointer stars of the Big Dipper constellation, which are the two stars at the end of the dipper's bowl. Imagine drawing a straight line from the pointer stars, and the North Star will be roughly five times the distance between those two stars in that same direction.

Please note that the exact position of the North Star may vary slightly based on your location and the time of year, but generally, it should be directly north when you are facing that direction.
